image.altText: A woman in glasses sitting in a power wheelchair.

items.synopsis: A disability advocate's call for all Adelaide taxis to be made fully accessible is being considered by the SA government — but it says a solution will not be in next week's state budget.

title.children: Unreliable access taxis 'compromise safety' of people with disabilities, advocate says

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has increased the cash rate to 4.1 per cent at its June meeting, citing "persistent" and "ongoing" high inflation. It's the highest cash rate since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: Reserve Bank lifts cash rate to 4.1 per cent, but won't rule out 'further tightening' to tackle inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages. "Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement. "While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued." In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's slightly bigger than expected rise in minimum and award wages, which was the highest in decades. "Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed. "Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year. "At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up." In contrast — Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week. (Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What has Philip Lowe said about the rate rise?

children.content: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages.
"Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement.

"While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued."
In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's
slightly bigger than expected rise in
minimum and award wages
, which was the highest in decades.
"Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed.
"Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year.
"At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up."
In contrast — Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week.
(Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is speaking in Canberra now in response to the RBA's rate rise. He's reiterated the point made by RBA governor Philip Lowe at Senate Estimates last week, who said the federal budget was not increasing inflation in the economy. Here's some of what he had to say: "This rate rise today is not because of the budget and not because people on the minimum wage are being paid too much," he said. "This rate rise is because inflation is more persistent in the economy than any of us would like. "We have acted decisively in the budget to address cost of living pressures ... the RBA governor made it clear that he budget is taking pressure off inflation. "This is a difficult day for Australians."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer: 'This is a difficult day for Australians'

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is speaking in Canberra now in response to the RBA's rate rise.
He's reiterated the point made by RBA governor Philip Lowe at Senate Estimates last week, who said the federal budget was not increasing inflation in the economy.
Here's some of what he had to say:
"This rate rise today is not because of the budget and not because people on the minimum wage are being paid too much," he said.
"This rate rise is because inflation is more persistent in the economy than any of us would like.
"We have acted decisively in the budget to address cost of living pressures ... the RBA governor made it clear that he budget is taking pressure off inflation.
"This is a difficult day for Australians."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're a mortgage holder and trying to make sense of how much extra your repayments could be now the cash rate is 4.1%, we have a calculator to help figure it out. If you plug in the size of your loan, term and interest rate, the calculator will tell you what your repayments might look like now. (If you want to bookmark this calculator and come back to it later, you can also find it below 👇 )

image.altText: a skyline with houses

items.synopsis: Interest rates climb above 4 per cent for the first time in more than 11 years, as the Reserve Bank moves aggressively to clamp down on inflation.

title.children: Cash rate surges past 4 per cent as RBA hikes again

image.altText: Chau with his mother-in-law, wife Trang and son Daniel.

items.synopsis: The family of a retired Sydney baker jailed in Vietnam for 12 years on "terrorism" offences express new hope for his freedom after Anthony Albanese's visit to the South-East Asian nation.

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

image.altText: A young man.

image.altText: A close up of Angus speaking against a dark blue background.

image.altText: Two middle aged women leaning together with big smiles

image.altText: a woman lying on the green grass with a baby by her side

image.altText: Image of a CCTV camera in front of street art of Aboriginal girl

image.altText: A woman outside a court building in handcuffs.

items.synopsis: Crystal Leanne Hanley is granted home detention bail to clean up her SA Housing rental property, which the prosecutor has described as being "unsuitable for human habitation".

image.altText: A large grassy hill surrounded by trees, with a large patch of burnt grass visible

image.altText: Tasmanian petrol prices falling

title.children: Man uses employer's fuel card to unlawfully buy more than $20k of petrol

image.altText: A young woman standing at a cash register looks at a woman sorting her groceries in a trolley.

items.synopsis: The odds have been shortening on the Reserve Bank of Australia lifting interest rates again, and Australia's workers are once more being blamed for driving inflation, writes David Peetz.

image.altText: A birds eye view of a mine with a pit and a pool of water.

items.synopsis: This Bougainville community is living on a literal goldmine, but some residents say that despite it being abandoned for decades, it poses a risk to their environment and human rights.

title.children: The waters in this part of a remote jungle are so blue there are fears over what runs in them

image.altText: A man wearing a car backwards stands by a bright green car, with its doors open.

image.altText: a man wearing a suit standing in front of video and photo cameras

title.children: Five key findings from the Ben Roberts-Smith judgement

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith receives Victoria Cross

title.children: Three ADF failures built the culture that enabled Ben Roberts-Smith

image.altText: woman looks lovingly at her chihuahua puppy who fits in her hand
